ADVICE_PAGE.CARD_1_CONTENT: Epilepsy is a chronic neurological disorder characterized by recurrent seizures due to abnormal electrical activity in the brain. It is neither contagious nor a mental illness.
ADVICE_PAGE.CARD_2_CONTENT: Seizures are classified into two main groups: generalized (affecting the whole brain) and focal (starting in one area). Symptoms include convulsions, loss of consciousness, or unusual sensations.
ADVICE_PAGE.CARD_3_CONTENT: No, febrile seizures are common in young children and are often benign. They do not necessarily mean the child has epilepsy, but a medical evaluation is recommended.
ADVICE_PAGE.CARD_4_CONTENT: Stay calm, protect the person from injury (move dangerous objects away), place something soft under their head, do NOT put anything in their mouth, and time the seizure. Call emergency services if it lasts longer than 5 minutes.
ADVICE_PAGE.CARD_5_CONTENT: Common myths include swallowing the tongue or epilepsy being contagious. In reality, with proper treatment, most people with epilepsy live full, active lives.
ADVICE_PAGE.CARD_6_CONTENT: Medication is crucial but often not enough on its own. A healthy lifestyle (regular sleep, stress management) and strict adherence to treatment plans are key to controlling seizures.
ADVICE_PAGE.ARTICLE_DESC: Epilepsy research is progressing rapidly. Discover new treatment options, innovative detection devices, and how these advances are transforming patients' daily lives. An in-depth analysis by our experts.
